etymologies: late Middle English; earliest use found in Knyghthode and Bataile. From classical Latin crīminōsus (of persons) prone to vituperation, (of speeches) accusatory, reflecting badly on a person, shameful, dishonouring, constituting a criminal offence, guilty of an offence, vicious from crīmin-, crīmen + -ōsus. Compare Anglo-Norman criminous, criminose and Middle French crimineux (noun) person guilty of a crime, Middle French, French crimineux (adjective) criminal

definitions: Of a person: guilty of a crime; criminal; (also) accused of a crime. Also as noun: (with the) guilty or criminal people as a class.

notes.text: Frequently used with reference to a member of the clergy.

definitions: Of a thing: characterized by crime or grave offence; criminal.
